Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: Today was supposed to be a day of celebration—my younger sister had just been accepted into her dream university, and our family planned a small gathering at home. As her brother, I knew how much it meant to her that I be there, cheering her on, sharing in her joy. But as I was about to leave the clinic, a patient walked in, coughing and sniffling, complaining of what seemed like a common cold. As a doctor, I couldn’t just brush off his symptoms; I had to be thorough, run the necessary tests, and make sure it wasn’t something more serious. My phone buzzed with messages from my sister, asking when I’d arrive. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—my family expecting my presence, my patient needing my attention. Torn between the duty to my sister and my responsibility as a doctor, I stood in the hallway, heart pounding, unable to ignore the pull of either side.
